channel.title: [JavaScript] Least significant bit
channel.description:
I am trying to get the least significant bit of a number in JavaScript.
I have the following code:
[code=java](parseInt("110", 2) & 0xffff)[/code]
By my understanding, the least significant bit of 110 is 1[b]1[/b]0 as it is the right-most set bit.
However, the code above returns '6', which is the total value of 110 and not the least significant bit.
How can I get the least significant bit?
[hr]
Looks like I was misunderstanding what the least significant bit is. It is always the right-most column, not the right-most set column.
Therefore with the following code:
[code]parseInt("110", 2) & 1[/code]
I can get 0, and with:
[code]parseInt("111", 2) & 1[/code]
I can get 1.

item.title: [JavaScript] Least significant bit
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Masking with 0xffff will actually get you the 16 least significant bits.
As sini said, you’re after the least significant active bit. I don’t think you can calculate this without iterating.

Start with the mask 0x1 and, in a loop, left-shift it one bit at a time until mask & value returns a non-zero value.

Read full topic

item.title: [JavaScript] Least significant bit
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

I’m not sure what you’re working on but it may be useful to let you know that ES6 allows you to prepend a raw bit-string with 0b and it will interpret it as such. ie. 0b110 => 6.

Read full topic
